This should not be a problem in normal use and I would not expect a metal case for this price.  The connection lead allows either a USB or a USB C socket to be used via a built in adapter (pic 2).  The sockets are of the push in and pull out type commonly found on laptops and desktops that is not the 'click in/out' kind you would find in a camera say.I particularly needed the CF (Compact Flash) card socket.  I have an old camera that uses this format but despite being old it still takes very nice pictures and so this hub has given it a new lease of life.  We also own a couple of cheap point and shoot cameras that use MS format cards so that is a bonus.  I had had a CF card slot on my desktop computer but that died when one of my little treasures tried to ram the card in upside down.  Oh well history is history and long since forgotten.For thoroughness sake I tried all of the sockets both through a USB and USB C connection and moved the same 1Gb of files back and forth to each type of card and an on board disk.  While there was some difference in the various performances these were mostly down to the motley selection of cards I own/used.  The bottom line is they all worked and transferred fast enough not to be a nuisance or a go and get a cup of coffee now moment.  With a decent SD card the transfer took a few seconds.  More than acceptable.  The hub is plenty fast enough just don't expect it to supercharge very old and slow cards.  But it will chug along nicely as fast as they can go and certainly will not be the factor limiting the speed of any transfers.  Incidentally you can happily use all 4 sockets at once.A good quality and cheap solution to my broken CF card slot that has the bonus of 3 other slots for commonly available cards.  I like these kinds of hubs and they do make it a bit easier to get the cards in an out particularly with a laptop.  If these are the sockets you need then this is a very good buy.
